On Wed, 02 Jun 2004 23:15:50 +0100, Colin Green <cgreen@...> wrote:
> But whenever a neuron is added it can *never* be
> immediately beneficial because NEAT adds them in such a way as to make
> them equivalent to the connection that was split. 

As Ken has already pointed out, that's not technically correct.  NEAT
mitigates the impact of adding a neuron by making the incoming weight
1 and the outgoing weight the same as the previous connection...but a
nonlinearity has been added where there was none before.

> Yes I see your point. Expressing all of the junk in the phenotype may
> work to some extent but it wouldn't be very efficient. 

I don't think it would work very well at all.  You mentioned birds
carrying around dinosaur DNA.  Obviously, they don't actually express
all of that DNA.  To do so would not only be inefficient, it would
most likely be fatal.

> Well my code includes disabled genes in determining compatibility, and
> I'm pretty sure I based this on Ken's NEAT code/papers. Perhaps what we
> need then is some library of structures external to the population of
> genomes. A new mutation could be to randomly insert pieces of structure
> from this library into a genome. That way you get the as-yet-unproven
> benefit of 'junk DNA' without the baggage of having to carry it around
> in the genomes. If a useful 'chunk' is found then it then becomes part
> of a genome and subject to propogation through the population through
> the normal means of crossover and asexual reproduction.

Yes, that's a possibility.  Some other neuroevolutionary techniques
already sort of work this way.  SANE actually builds genomes (I think
it calls them "blueprints") from pools of genetic material.  Joseph's
modular NEAT also keeps a seperate pool of subnets that can mutate
into new offspring.

But in each of these, the stuff kept in the pool is continually
evaluated to weed out the junk.  I think the general principle holds
that the more untested junk you have, the larger its going to make
your search.

> >Right...but the useless structures are not generally kept around.  You
> >don't see organisms with lots of useless organs or appendages just
> >waiting to become useful.
> >
> Well that's not entirely true. If the useless appendages hinder the
> organism or require a significant resources to grow and/or maintain then
> individuals with these characteristics will be selected against over
> time. But if the appendages aren't too expensive and aren't getting in
> the way then they can indeed stick around. One that comes to mind is the
> human appendix, and I've never found my little toe to be all that
> useful. Well Ok you did say 'generally' - these 'extras' are mostly
> special cases. I agree with the general priniciple that organisms don't
> carry around loads of  appendages in the hope that one might become
> useful, like some biological equivalent of a swiss army knife :)

Well, I said "generally", but I also said "lots".  Of course there are
instances of vestigial organs, but they are often small, withered, and
negligible.  They are not doing enough harm to the organism to be
strongly selected against, and the likelihood they they will become
adaptive again at some later stage of evolution is remote.

Derek
